summary: This is a Petition for Probate and Letters Testamentary filed in the Superior Court of the Virgin Islands for the Estate of Jeffrey E. Epstein. It includes the will, death certificate, and details of the estate's executors and assets, which are valued at over $577 million. The document formally initiates the probate process following Epstein's death. This is the last will and testament of Jeffrey E. Epstein, executed on August 8, 2019, in New York. It details the extensive powers granted to his executors, including broad investment, business, and administrative authorities, and outlines provisions for tax payments, beneficiary disputes, and the incorporation of a separate trust agreement.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein's estate is valued at approximately $577,672,654.00, including cash, investments, real estate, and other assets.
Epstein's last will, dated August 8, 2019, appoints Darren K. Indyke and Richard D. Kahn as executors, with Boris Nikolic as successor executor.
Epstein's death certificate states he died on August 10, 2019, in New York, NY, and was domiciled in St. Thomas, US Virgin Islands.
Mark Epstein is identified as Jeffrey Epstein's brother and sole heir, entitled to 100% of the estate if there were no will.
The estate's significant assets include properties in New York, New Mexico, Florida, France, and private islands in the US Virgin Islands.
Jeffrey E. Epstein's will was executed on August 8, 2019, just two days before his death.
The will grants executors extremely broad powers over the estate's assets, including the authority to retain, sell, invest, and manage all property without being limited by typical investment laws.
It includes specific provisions to disinherit any beneficiary who contests the will or the validity of its dispositions or the associated trust agreement.
The will references a separate 'Trust Agreement' and incorporates its provisions, indicating a significant portion of the estate was planned to be held in trust.
The document outlines complex rules for tax apportionment, particularly for assets not passing under the will or trust (Apportionment Assets).
